title: 105_hr1271
content: The Act may be cited as the "FAA Research, Engineering, and Development Authorization Act of 1998" and authorizes appropriations. Section 48102(a) of title 49, United States Code is amended to allocate $226,800,000 for various aviation technology projects and activities for fiscal year 1998. This includes funding for system development, capacity, air traffic management, communications, navigation, surveillance, weather, airport technology, and aircraft safety technology projects. For fiscal year 1999, funding allocations include $49,202,000 for aircraft safety technology, $53,759,000 for system security technology, $26,550,000 for human factors and aviation medicine, $2,891,000 for environment and energy, and $3,114,000 for innovative/cooperative research projects. Total funding for the year is $229,673,000. SEC. 3. RESEARCH GRANTS PROGRAM INVOLVING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS. The Federal Aviation Administration will establish a research grants program involving undergraduate and technical colleges, including Historically Black Colleges and Universities and Hispanic Serving Institutions, to conduct research relevant to the agency. Grants may be awarded for research projects at these institutions or in collaboration with other FAA-supported research. The Federal Aviation Administration will establish a research grants program for research relevant to the agency, including future training requirements and regulatory changes for aircraft maintenance. Criteria for grant proposals and awards will be published within 6 months of the FAA Research, Engineering, and Development Authorization Act of 1998. The Federal Aviation Administration will establish a research grants program for relevant research, focusing on scientific merit, undergraduate student participation, and competitive evaluation. Authorization of appropriations includes $750,000 for the grant program. SEC. 4. NOTICES. Reprogramming of funds authorized by this Act requires notice to Appropriations Committees of the House and Senate, as well as Committees on Science, Transportation and Infrastructure, and Commerce, Science, and Transportation. The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration must notify relevant committees 30 days before any major reorganization of FAA programs funded by this Act. With the year 2000 approaching, Congress urges the Federal Aviation Administration to prioritize fixing date-related computer system issues, assess risks, budget for Year 2000 compliance, and develop contingency plans for systems that cannot be corrected in time.
